newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares end slightly lower, range-bound.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end slightly lower, range-bound.

text.p: Late short covering pulled shares from a slide to finish little changed on Thursday but the undercurrent was shaky, brokers said.
The 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) closed 0.21 points down at a provisional 2,880.05, after moving between 2,850.06 and 2,893.70.
"The market attracted short-covering towards the close. Otherwise, it was a very dull day," said Mehul Patel, dealer at Mukesh Babu Securities Ltd.
The 50-share National Stock Exchange index dropped 3.35 points to a provisional 823.65.
The net traded value was 7.46 billion rupees in 35 million shares at the NSE.
He said business was mostly of position-squaring because of the last day of weekly account at the BSE.
Traders expect carry-forward charges to stay low as buyers were mostly foreign funds who do not carry-forward trades but take delivery.
"Technically, the market looks ripe for rebound," said one analyst. "But confidence levels are low."
Bajaj Auto rallied 15.75 rupees to 740 and Gujarat Ambuja Cement 10.50 to 232 on foreign fund buying and scattered short covering, traders said.
ACC firmed 10.50 rupees to 1,010.50, Indian Hotel 13.75 to 675 and Hindustan Ciba 59 to 3,000.
Nestle fell 18.0 rupees to 177, Ranbaxy 4.25 to 520, Hindustan Lever 9.25 to 781, ITC 5.0 to 278.50 and M&M 2.25 to 308.75.
